instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
Minor liquid damage.

Fan spins for a couple of seconds then repeats.


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> jumps from 0.2 to something as fan goes on and off
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> jumps from 0.6 to something as fan goes on and off.

Cannot see anything on either of these lines that is suspicious.

Diode mode <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0.430
Diode mode <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0.389 (matches donor)

Wanted to see if it was the S3 or the S0 causing the issue. Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>. With <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> removed <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 5v.
Suspected <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>, replaced it.
Board turned on for 30 seconds with normal fan.
Unplugged, waited and tested again - Back to same problem, quarter fan spin.

Vcore when quarter fan spinning is not coming on.

Begin to suspect <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> ?
Appreciate any help as always.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
Both look and measure ok (180K and 150k).

On pin 2 (input) i get a totally steady 12.56v
On pin 1 (both, seperatley) I get 12.33v, which jumps (very quick change on multimeter - decimal point jumps about with fan pulse)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>? How do the BIOS traces look and the clock chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
Do you get a pulse at the big coils (apart the CPU ones)?
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
ISL looks fine. 4ohm and 20.4ohm on the readings.

Do get pulses at the big coils PP1V5, <SIGNAL>PP5_S3</SIGNAL> etc. Nothing on CPU ones.

No change in SMC bypass mode.

Wanted to see if it was the S3 or the S0 causing the issue. Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>. With <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> removed <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 5v.
Suspected <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>, replaced it.
Board turned on for 30 seconds with normal fan.
Unplugged, waited and tested again - Back to same problem, quarter fan spin.

Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
Resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>?
Do you get again steady <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> without <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
resistance to ground of <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>  28k

Yes <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is present at 5v if <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> is removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message: If i heat <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> it will boot a whole OS and run until shut off. I tried replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> again, and all the surrounding components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
The heat affects probably other areas of the logic board...
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7860</RESISTOR>/62.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message:
Thanks, Was just looking at <TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced it  (have already replaced <RESISTOR>R7860</RESISTOR>/62)
Real head scratcher.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Quarter Fan spin
threads.message: Fucking ultrasonic fixed it. Thanks for your help.
